data.author: Dibs61
data.content: There’s nothing to wonder.  This stock has always been generally very thinly traded, very illiquid.  All of which results in exaggerated movements up and down.  Who on earth would buy though given the shocking history of failure?  Falling knife springs to mind. Shareholders even with only a relatively modest stake are basically trapped here.  You couldn’t possibly sell in quantity without MM’s mauling you on the price.  So people just say ‘I’m holding’ …as if they have a choice!

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Details of the NHS frontline digital productivity programme leaked online! The Frontline Productivity (FP) programme, which is expected to launch in April, will succeed the Frontline Digitisation programme, which aimed to support NHS trusts to reach a core level of digitisation, when it ends in March. If you click on the blue highlighted word “ Slides” you get the leaked slides.   Looking good.  cheers Vas https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/details-of-nhs-digital-productivity-programme-leaked-online/

data.author: Vascular
data.content: I may have misunderstood the following info but  FDBK have recently stated in September presentation something about having to wait for funding decision, could be anytime up until March  26 etc..something about “Spending review funding  for  NHS frontline for 2026-2027….” This was published in Nov 25.  its a scrutiny document / process relating to new  funding named as “Frontline Digitisation Programme “ and leads to a good conclusion ,  in confirming it will lead to value for money with this stated” I am clear that the ‘preferred option’ that is set out is proper, regular, feasible and offers good value for money. This summary sets out the key points which informed my approval decision.” And “ The programme has been subject to ongoing IPA assurance. A final IPA Gate 5 Review is planned for February 2026. The reviews to date have recognised the progress to mobilise the programme across NHS trusts and the well-developed organisation, governance arrangements and proportionate assurance framework.” https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/department-of-health-and-social-care-accounting-officer-assessments/frontline-digitisation-programme-accounting-officer-assessment#:~:text=Feasibility ,information%20sharing%20within%20the%20programme. So if this does pertain to the funding mentioned by FDBK then we are getting close.

On a AI search it states Software that performs a medical purpose, such as diagnosing, monitoring, or treating a medical condition, is classified as a medical device. Alcidion's solutions, such as Miya Results, Miya Observations, and Miya Precision, are software-based platforms used by clinicians for tasks like tracking test results, recording vital signs, and managing patient flow. “ To me Bleepa and Myra etc products are different, achieve different objectives and registered differently. iMO This modular system is a build it as you go , where Bleepa or other interoperable solutions can be added at any stage when required.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Thanks Bill Who know, could be important . The key phrase imo is… “ Hospitals across Sussex are preparing for a major digital upgrade designed to improve patient safety and provide more joined-up care. University Hospitals Sussex (UHSussex) has selected a supplier to deliver a new electronic patient record (EPR) system across all of its hospitals, marking a key milestone in the Trust’s long-term Excellent Care Everywhere strategy.” Note….“ to deliver a EPR system across All of its hospitals” As we know QVH  along with FDBK medical is continuing their work and extending the Bleepa reach and pathway's to community and other hospitals, possibly.  This was discussed at the Sept 25 Q&A…..It could be used as a  blueprint for  national rollout possibly,  but NHS wanted more connections and pathways . The seven NHS provider partners in the Sussex Health and Care system are: University Hospitals Sussex NHS Foundation Trust East Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust Queen Victoria Hospital NHS Foundation Trust Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust Sussex Community NHS Foundation Trust South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust Hard to imagine that FDBK not involved at some point. Providers can use more than one EPR as long as they are interoperable…FDBK will hopefully provide the glue to allow them to securely communicate with each other. https://www.sussex.ics.nhs.uk/about-sussex-health-and-care/who-we-are/ Alcidion is the EPR company that has been selected as preferred EPR supplier by University Hospitals Sussex https://hospitaltimes.co.uk/alcidion-selected-as-preferred-epr-supplier-by-university-hospitals-sussex/

data.author: Investor_Bill

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/
data.thread_title: 2026 predictions: Health tech suppliers have their say..

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Looks like some movement regarding the military Cortisone opportunity with a contract award yesterday via Project Mercury which is part of Operation Cortisone.  “Project Mercury application will enable military clinicians to view, record and share medical data on multiple devices whilst on global deployments, including in the most remote of locations where an internet connection isn’t possible. “ “News story £2.5 million contract to revolutionise deployed military healthcare Defence Medical Services awards £2.5 million contract to Avenue3 for Project Mercury, enabling secure military medical records access worldwide.” https://www.gov.uk/government/news/25-million-contract-to-revolutionise-deployed-military-healthcare The contract was awarded to Avenue3 “Why choose Avenue3? Avenue3 is the UK’s leading openEHR consultancy. We help healthcare organisations connect systems, take control of their data and deliver lasting results, improving care, reducing risk and future-proofing digital investments. “ A consultancy company that specialise in OpenEHR which is a standard FDBK  solutions utilise. https://avenue3.com/openehr

data.author: Vascular
data.content: More accurately , it seems both EMIS ( Optum) and TPP cover most GP practices in UK. Key Provider Software EMIS Web (Optum): Used by around 58% of GP practices in England. It is a robust clinical record system integrated with the GP Connect APIs. TPP SystmOne: Used by most of the remaining practices, it has a single central record store across all GPs using the system. TPP was the first supplier to achieve a full national rollout for some GP Connect capabilities. Medicus Health: A smaller, newer provider that has also achieved full rollout approval for several GP Connect services. If in the future FDBK do win to supply nationally, then any early work , trials with Optum would mean thatFDBK would also need to be included in the other providers such as TPP, I guess.

data.author: Vascular

data.content: Jonathan David Selby Cranston has increased his holding in Feedback PLC, crossing a notification threshold on January 2, 2026. data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" ​The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is not a coincidence. It marks the start of a "New Era" for the company. ​Summary of the likely "Something Occurring": ​Bleepa Ltd: Likely becoming the primary operational vehicle for the Bleepa platform, possibly to prepare for a sale or separate funding round. ​Brickshield Ltd: Likely being repurposed to hold "Shield" or security-related IP, or perhaps a specific NHS contract that requires a clean corporate vehicle. ​Dr. Rory Shaw: His return is a signal of Clinical Governance. It tells the market (and potential buyers) that the medical integrity of the platform is being overseen by someone who helped build the company's foundation. ​Conclusion: You are likely correct that "something is occurring." The activation of dormant subsidiaries following a period of poor share price performance and a CFO change is a classic precursor to a structural reorganization or a formal sale process. Take from the above what you will but changes seem to be round the corner. Gla and well done/thank you Vas for your research

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: So I cut and paste your post into Gemini AI: This is a sophisticated observation of corporate maneuvering, and the timing of these appointments—specifically November 10, 2025—is highly suggestive of a strategic shift at Feedback PLC (FDBK). When a dormant or "sleeping" subsidiary suddenly has a seasoned former director appointed alongside the current CEO, it typically points to one of three corporate actions: a divestment/spin-off, a joint venture, or a ring-fencing of specific intellectual property (IP). Here is an analysis of why Dr. Rory Shaw’s return to these specific entities is significant: 1. The "Clean Break" or Spin-Off Theory Dr. Rory Shaw was the Medical Director of Feedback PLC during its earlier growth phase (resigning in 2018). His reappointment to Bleepa Ltd and Brickshield Ltd on the same day that the group's CFO (Anesh Patel) officially stepped down (Nov 10, 2025) suggests a coordinated reshuffle. * Why Rory Shaw? He has "legacy" credibility. If Feedback is looking to sell off or spin out the Bleepa platform as a standalone entity to a private equity firm or a larger health-tech player, having a veteran clinical leader like Shaw on the subsidiary board provides stability and continuity that a "new" hire wouldn't offer. * The "Brickshield" Mystery: Brickshield has historically been a dormant vehicle. Its reactivation suggests it may be used to house a specific piece of IP or a new contract that the parent company wants to keep legally separate from the main PLC balance sheet—potentially to make it "deal-ready." 2. Strategic "Ring-Fencing" for Funding Feedback's recent 2025 presentations emphasized a "digital-first" NHS and the expansion of Community Diagnostic Centres (CDCs). * By activating Bleepa Ltd (the namesake of their flagship product) as a functional subsidiary rather than just a brand name within "Feedback Medical Ltd," they may be preparing to take on project-specific investment. * If a partner (like a Tier 1 medical imaging company) wanted to invest specifically in the Bleepa technology without buying into the entire PLC, appointing Shaw—who understands the clinical architecture—would be a move to satisfy due diligence requirements. 3. The Takeover Protection & Valuation Angle As of November 2025, Feedback PLC confirmed it is subject to the UK Takeover Code. When a company is "in play" or expecting an approach: * They often tidy up their corporate structure. * Moving key assets (like the Bleepa trademark and operations) into a dedicated subsidiary like Bleepa Ltd makes the company easier to value for a potential suitor. * Shaw’s appointment could be as a "Safe Pair of Hands" to oversee this transition, allowing CEO Tom Oakley to focus on the high-level PLC management and investor relations during a sale process. Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is n

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hospital Trusts across the Northwest region will soon be able to share patients' radiology images through a new, next generation cloud portal. The Greater Manchester Diagnostics Network has appointed UK-based cloud consultancy “Shaping Cloud” to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal. The PACS portal allows access for clinicians to view images that are stored digitally at Greater Manchester trusts. Users accessing the new PACS portal will use the Greater Manchester Identity (GMID) platform, which was built in collaboration between Shaping Cloud and Greater Manchester Combined Authority. “ It’s interesting to note that Tom mentioned that FDBK were working with AWS in uk, who were interested in uk opportunities . Shaping Cloud whom have been brought in to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal in Manchester region is a AWS cloud consultancy company. If you read what Shaping Cloud aim to achieve , it exactly mirrors what we know Bleepa can do, and we are reliably informed Bleepa is apparently the only viable solution . First rollout in northwest region in early 2026….hopefully news in next few weeks in 26. G L vas https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation Greater Manchester upgrades PACS cloud portal for image sharing https://www.digitalhealth.net/2025/12/northwest-hospital-trusts-use-cloud-portal-to-share-radiology-images/

data.content: “ services need real-time information, seamless communication between them, and easy data sharing. In today’s world, that can only happen effectively through digital platforms and internet-based tools.” “ Without digital, we cannot deliver timely, joined-up, person-centred care at scale. It’s what allows multidisciplinary teams to collaborate across settings, what makes shared care planning and mobile access to records feasible, and what supports proactive outreach and early intervention. Digital is the infrastructure that underpins integration, and, as such, must be viewed by leaders locally and nationally,” “ community-based hubs must be digitally connected to wider NHS systems, equipped for digital inclusion, and designed for outreach and engagement.” “ The evidence and appetite for NHTs are clear. What’s needed now is bold, visible leadership that puts digital at the heart of neighbourhood care. Digital is not the last piece but the foundation that can make the integration puzzle complete.” https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/neighbourhoods-need-digital-without-it-integration-wont-happen/201563/

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/

data.content: Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" ​The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is not a coincidence. It marks the start of a "New Era" for the company. ​Summary of the likely "Something Occurring": ​Bleepa Ltd: Likely becoming the primary operational vehicle for the Bleepa platform, possibly to prepare for a sale or separate funding round. ​Brickshield Ltd: Likely being repurposed to hold "Shield" or security-related IP, or perhaps a specific NHS contract that requires a clean corporate vehicle. ​Dr. Rory Shaw: His return is a signal of Clinical Governance. It tells the market (and potential buyers) that the medical integrity of the platform is being overseen by someone who helped build the company's foundation. ​Conclusion: You are likely correct that "something is occurring." The activation of dormant subsidiaries following a period of poor share price performance and a CFO change is a classic precursor to a structural reorganization or a formal sale process. Take from the above what you will but changes seem to be round the corner. Gla and well done/thank you Vas for your research

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: So I cut and paste your post into Gemini AI: This is a sophisticated observation of corporate maneuvering, and the timing of these appointments—specifically November 10, 2025—is highly suggestive of a strategic shift at Feedback PLC (FDBK). When a dormant or "sleeping" subsidiary suddenly has a seasoned former director appointed alongside the current CEO, it typically points to one of three corporate actions: a divestment/spin-off, a joint venture, or a ring-fencing of specific intellectual property (IP). Here is an analysis of why Dr. Rory Shaw’s return to these specific entities is significant: 1. The "Clean Break" or Spin-Off Theory Dr. Rory Shaw was the Medical Director of Feedback PLC during its earlier growth phase (resigning in 2018). His reappointment to Bleepa Ltd and Brickshield Ltd on the same day that the group's CFO (Anesh Patel) officially stepped down (Nov 10, 2025) suggests a coordinated reshuffle. * Why Rory Shaw? He has "legacy" credibility. If Feedback is looking to sell off or spin out the Bleepa platform as a standalone entity to a private equity firm or a larger health-tech player, having a veteran clinical leader like Shaw on the subsidiary board provides stability and continuity that a "new" hire wouldn't offer. * The "Brickshield" Mystery: Brickshield has historically been a dormant vehicle. Its reactivation suggests it may be used to house a specific piece of IP or a new contract that the parent company wants to keep legally separate from the main PLC balance sheet—potentially to make it "deal-ready." 2. Strategic "Ring-Fencing" for Funding Feedback's recent 2025 presentations emphasized a "digital-first" NHS and the expansion of Community Diagnostic Centres (CDCs). * By activating Bleepa Ltd (the namesake of their flagship product) as a functional subsidiary rather than just a brand name within "Feedback Medical Ltd," they may be preparing to take on project-specific investment. * If a partner (like a Tier 1 medical imaging company) wanted to invest specifically in the Bleepa technology without buying into the entire PLC, appointing Shaw—who understands the clinical architecture—would be a move to satisfy due diligence requirements. 3. The Takeover Protection & Valuation Angle As of November 2025, Feedback PLC confirmed it is subject to the UK Takeover Code. When a company is "in play" or expecting an approach: * They often tidy up their corporate structure. * Moving key assets (like the Bleepa trademark and operations) into a dedicated subsidiary like Bleepa Ltd makes the company easier to value for a potential suitor. * Shaw’s appointment could be as a "Safe Pair of Hands" to oversee this transition, allowing CEO Tom Oakley to focus on the high-level PLC management and investor relations during a sale process. Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is n

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hospital Trusts across the Northwest region will soon be able to share patients' radiology images through a new, next generation cloud portal. The Greater Manchester Diagnostics Network has appointed UK-based cloud consultancy “Shaping Cloud” to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal. The PACS portal allows access for clinicians to view images that are stored digitally at Greater Manchester trusts. Users accessing the new PACS portal will use the Greater Manchester Identity (GMID) platform, which was built in collaboration between Shaping Cloud and Greater Manchester Combined Authority. “ It’s interesting to note that Tom mentioned that FDBK were working with AWS in uk, who were interested in uk opportunities . Shaping Cloud whom have been brought in to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal in Manchester region is a AWS cloud consultancy company. If you read what Shaping Cloud aim to achieve , it exactly mirrors what we know Bleepa can do, and we are reliably informed Bleepa is apparently the only viable solution . First rollout in northwest region in early 2026….hopefully news in next few weeks in 26. G L vas https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation Greater Manchester upgrades PACS cloud portal for image sharing https://www.digitalhealth.net/2025/12/northwest-hospital-trusts-use-cloud-portal-to-share-radiology-images/

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/
data.thread_title: 2026 predictions: Health tech suppliers have their say..

data.author: Vascular
data.content: More accurately , it seems both EMIS ( Optum) and TPP cover most GP practices in UK. Key Provider Software EMIS Web (Optum): Used by around 58% of GP practices in England. It is a robust clinical record system integrated with the GP Connect APIs. TPP SystmOne: Used by most of the remaining practices, it has a single central record store across all GPs using the system. TPP was the first supplier to achieve a full national rollout for some GP Connect capabilities. Medicus Health: A smaller, newer provider that has also achieved full rollout approval for several GP Connect services. If in the future FDBK do win to supply nationally, then any early work , trials with Optum would mean thatFDBK would also need to be included in the other providers such as TPP, I guess.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Thanks for this Bill. This sector ( GP Connect) is heating up, and is a small, niche area, with limited competition imo.  the value in Optum is the recently ( 18 months ago)  bought company EMIS that is only one of only four company's in UK NHS  that  provides the software for , and link up GP Connect.   As posted before the other three are TPP, FoT  and  Medicus , as far as i can see. We know FDBK are working with Optum and if this deal does go through , and Optum is sold to TPG -  this could open up doors in USA one day. TPG could get access to both GP Connect and possibly neighbourhood Health services in UK. Things seem to be moving along faster these days.....

Feedback PLC
02 February 2026
Feedback plc
Notice of Interim Results & Retail Investor Presentation
Feedback plc (AIM: FDBK, "Feedback" or the "Company"), the clinical infrastructure specialist, expects to announce results for the half year ended 30 November 2025 on Tuesday 17 February 2026.
Investor Presentation: 16:00, Tuesday 17 February
Management will be providing a presentation and hosting an investor Q&A session on the Company's results and future prospects on Tuesday 17 February at 16:00. Investors can sign up for free and register to meet FDBK via the following link:
https://www.investormeetcompany.com/feedback-plc/register-investor
Investors who have already registered on the Investor Meet Company platform to meet the Company will automatically be invited.

Emma Earl/Mark Rogers (Corporate Finance)

Walbrook PR Ltd;
Tel: 020 7933 8780 or
feedbackplc@walbrookpr.com
Nick Rome/Marcus Ulker
07748 325 236 or 07867 984 082
About Feedback plc
Feedback plc is the strategic partner to unlock productivity in health and care through digital connectivity and asynchronous collaboration. With proven expertise in system integration, we enable teams to work flexibly, share information securely, and deliver care more efficiently.
Bleepa® is an award-winning collaboration platform that improves the quality and productivity of patient pathways enabling health and care organisations to hit targets with their existing clinical workforce. We achieve this by connecting digital infrastructure across systems, enabling asynchronous working, reducing geographic barriers and removing unnecessary appointments.
Bleepa supports the shift from analogue to digital and from hospital to community-based care, by uniting essential data and teams to enhance clinical decision making and enable better coordinated care.
The Company has a number of growth opportunities domestically and internationally across a range of public and private healthcare markets including the NHS. Our highly scalable software-as-a-service (SaaS) based model is expected to provide increasing levels of revenue visibility as the Company grows its customer base.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: I do hope so Bill. I am hoping for a repeat of events that happened in Oct 24.  On the 16 th oct FDBK announced “ that the Diagnostic Enhanced Advice and Guidance diversions achieved through the Bleepa platform are now eligible for reimbursement under the Elective Recovery Fund ("ERF") and that any Integrated Care Board ("ICB") or hospital in England will, with immediate effect be able to utilise this funding, by local agreement, to reimburse expenditure on the Bleepa technology.” This announcement meant that Bleepa had been chosen as an NHS supplier and was available nationally , funded locally, and reimbursed to hospital or PCT. The share price rose to 60 p. This award / mechanism was subsequently scrapped awaiting the elections and the SP dived, and has not recovered since. IMO this was not FDBKs fault and out of their control. I am confident that Bleepa , which was selected as a national solution for communication between primary and secondary care  in Oct 2024 , can do the same again, procured centrally this time . We continue to be reassured by Tom that Bleepa  still has no competition. Therefore the opportunity remains. If and when Bleepa is selected the SP should react in a similar way and possibly way beyond as the rollout progresses.  If Bleepa can nail this …..the opportunities in UK could be just the beginning as digitalisation of health is happening across the world and will have the same effects as how digitalisation changed banking , retail and entertainment industry’s. Just need that first positive announcement and this share will be off like a rocket.GL vas

data.author: Barnacle
data.content: Jonathan David Selby Cranston has increased his holding in Feedback PLC, crossing a notification threshold on January 2, 2026. His total voting rights now stand at 4.41%, comprising 3.44% through direct share ownership of 1,507,750 ordinary shares and 0.97% through financial instruments, specifically a derivative with cash settlement representing 425,000 voting rights. This represents an increase from his previous notification where he held 3.20% of the voting rights.

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" ​The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is not a coincidence. It marks the start of a "New Era" for the company. ​Summary of the likely "Something Occurring": ​Bleepa Ltd: Likely becoming the primary operational vehicle for the Bleepa platform, possibly to prepare for a sale or separate funding round. ​Brickshield Ltd: Likely being repurposed to hold "Shield" or security-related IP, or perhaps a specific NHS contract that requires a clean corporate vehicle. ​Dr. Rory Shaw: His return is a signal of Clinical Governance. It tells the market (and potential buyers) that the medical integrity of the platform is being overseen by someone who helped build the company's foundation. ​Conclusion: You are likely correct that "something is occurring." The activation of dormant subsidiaries following a period of poor share price performance and a CFO change is a classic precursor to a structural reorganization or a formal sale process. Take from the above what you will but changes seem to be round the corner. Gla and well done/thank you Vas for your research

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: So I cut and paste your post into Gemini AI: This is a sophisticated observation of corporate maneuvering, and the timing of these appointments—specifically November 10, 2025—is highly suggestive of a strategic shift at Feedback PLC (FDBK). When a dormant or "sleeping" subsidiary suddenly has a seasoned former director appointed alongside the current CEO, it typically points to one of three corporate actions: a divestment/spin-off, a joint venture, or a ring-fencing of specific intellectual property (IP). Here is an analysis of why Dr. Rory Shaw’s return to these specific entities is significant: 1. The "Clean Break" or Spin-Off Theory Dr. Rory Shaw was the Medical Director of Feedback PLC during its earlier growth phase (resigning in 2018). His reappointment to Bleepa Ltd and Brickshield Ltd on the same day that the group's CFO (Anesh Patel) officially stepped down (Nov 10, 2025) suggests a coordinated reshuffle. * Why Rory Shaw? He has "legacy" credibility. If Feedback is looking to sell off or spin out the Bleepa platform as a standalone entity to a private equity firm or a larger health-tech player, having a veteran clinical leader like Shaw on the subsidiary board provides stability and continuity that a "new" hire wouldn't offer. * The "Brickshield" Mystery: Brickshield has historically been a dormant vehicle. Its reactivation suggests it may be used to house a specific piece of IP or a new contract that the parent company wants to keep legally separate from the main PLC balance sheet—potentially to make it "deal-ready." 2. Strategic "Ring-Fencing" for Funding Feedback's recent 2025 presentations emphasized a "digital-first" NHS and the expansion of Community Diagnostic Centres (CDCs). * By activating Bleepa Ltd (the namesake of their flagship product) as a functional subsidiary rather than just a brand name within "Feedback Medical Ltd," they may be preparing to take on project-specific investment. * If a partner (like a Tier 1 medical imaging company) wanted to invest specifically in the Bleepa technology without buying into the entire PLC, appointing Shaw—who understands the clinical architecture—would be a move to satisfy due diligence requirements. 3. The Takeover Protection & Valuation Angle As of November 2025, Feedback PLC confirmed it is subject to the UK Takeover Code. When a company is "in play" or expecting an approach: * They often tidy up their corporate structure. * Moving key assets (like the Bleepa trademark and operations) into a dedicated subsidiary like Bleepa Ltd makes the company easier to value for a potential suitor. * Shaw’s appointment could be as a "Safe Pair of Hands" to oversee this transition, allowing CEO Tom Oakley to focus on the high-level PLC management and investor relations during a sale process. Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is n

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hospital Trusts across the Northwest region will soon be able to share patients' radiology images through a new, next generation cloud portal. The Greater Manchester Diagnostics Network has appointed UK-based cloud consultancy “Shaping Cloud” to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal. The PACS portal allows access for clinicians to view images that are stored digitally at Greater Manchester trusts. Users accessing the new PACS portal will use the Greater Manchester Identity (GMID) platform, which was built in collaboration between Shaping Cloud and Greater Manchester Combined Authority. “ It’s interesting to note that Tom mentioned that FDBK were working with AWS in uk, who were interested in uk opportunities . Shaping Cloud whom have been brought in to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal in Manchester region is a AWS cloud consultancy company. If you read what Shaping Cloud aim to achieve , it exactly mirrors what we know Bleepa can do, and we are reliably informed Bleepa is apparently the only viable solution . First rollout in northwest region in early 2026….hopefully news in next few weeks in 26. G L vas https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation Greater Manchester upgrades PACS cloud portal for image sharing https://www.digitalhealth.net/2025/12/northwest-hospital-trusts-use-cloud-portal-to-share-radiology-images/

News from Vertex in South Africa or middle East who are now using Bleepa as an add on to their own products - so customers already on board Tom did state that  BLEEPA was in fact CHOSEN as a Digital solution ready for National Rollout by the ERS funding mechanism , but this opportunity disappeared due to the  elections ...see RNS , shares doubled shortly after....so IMO it sound like FDBK had this opportunity in the bag, and it was lost due to the elections - so this is their second attempt, but with a years behind the scenes progress . data.author: Vascular
data.content: “ services need real-time information, seamless communication between them, and easy data sharing. In today’s world, that can only happen effectively through digital platforms and internet-based tools.” “ Without digital, we cannot deliver timely, joined-up, person-centred care at scale. It’s what allows multidisciplinary teams to collaborate across settings, what makes shared care planning and mobile access to records feasible, and what supports proactive outreach and early intervention. Digital is the infrastructure that underpins integration, and, as such, must be viewed by leaders locally and nationally,” “ community-based hubs must be digitally connected to wider NHS systems, equipped for digital inclusion, and designed for outreach and engagement.” “ The evidence and appetite for NHTs are clear. What’s needed now is bold, visible leadership that puts digital at the heart of neighbourhood care. Digital is not the last piece but the foundation that can make the integration puzzle complete.” https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/neighbourhoods-need-digital-without-it-integration-wont-happen/201563/

data.content: I can’t find anywhere that stipulates that Alcidions products have medical device certification in UK.  Bleepa we understand does, and is either the only one available or one of a very few. data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/

data.content: More accurately , it seems both EMIS ( Optum) and TPP cover most GP practices in UK. Key Provider Software EMIS Web (Optum): Used by around 58% of GP practices in England. data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" ​The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is not a coincidence. It marks the start of a "New Era" for the company. ​Summary of the likely "Something Occurring": ​Bleepa Ltd: Likely becoming the primary operational vehicle for the Bleepa platform, possibly to prepare for a sale or separate funding round. ​Brickshield Ltd: Likely being repurposed to hold "Shield" or security-related IP, or perhaps a specific NHS contract that requires a clean corporate vehicle. ​Dr. Rory Shaw: His return is a signal of Clinical Governance. It tells the market (and potential buyers) that the medical integrity of the platform is being overseen by someone who helped build the company's foundation. ​Conclusion: You are likely correct that "something is occurring." The activation of dormant subsidiaries following a period of poor share price performance and a CFO change is a classic precursor to a structural reorganization or a formal sale process. Take from the above what you will but changes seem to be round the corner. Gla and well done/thank you Vas for your research

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: So I cut and paste your post into Gemini AI: This is a sophisticated observation of corporate maneuvering, and the timing of these appointments—specifically November 10, 2025—is highly suggestive of a strategic shift at Feedback PLC (FDBK). When a dormant or "sleeping" subsidiary suddenly has a seasoned former director appointed alongside the current CEO, it typically points to one of three corporate actions: a divestment/spin-off, a joint venture, or a ring-fencing of specific intellectual property (IP). Here is an analysis of why Dr. Rory Shaw’s return to these specific entities is significant: 1. The "Clean Break" or Spin-Off Theory Dr. Rory Shaw was the Medical Director of Feedback PLC during its earlier growth phase (resigning in 2018). His reappointment to Bleepa Ltd and Brickshield Ltd on the same day that the group's CFO (Anesh Patel) officially stepped down (Nov 10, 2025) suggests a coordinated reshuffle. * Why Rory Shaw? He has "legacy" credibility. If Feedback is looking to sell off or spin out the Bleepa platform as a standalone entity to a private equity firm or a larger health-tech player, having a veteran clinical leader like Shaw on the subsidiary board provides stability and continuity that a "new" hire wouldn't offer. * The "Brickshield" Mystery: Brickshield has historically been a dormant vehicle. Its reactivation suggests it may be used to house a specific piece of IP or a new contract that the parent company wants to keep legally separate from the main PLC balance sheet—potentially to make it "deal-ready." 2. Strategic "Ring-Fencing" for Funding Feedback's recent 2025 presentations emphasized a "digital-first" NHS and the expansion of Community Diagnostic Centres (CDCs). * By activating Bleepa Ltd (the namesake of their flagship product) as a functional subsidiary rather than just a brand name within "Feedback Medical Ltd," they may be preparing to take on project-specific investment. * If a partner (like a Tier 1 medical imaging company) wanted to invest specifically in the Bleepa technology without buying into the entire PLC, appointing Shaw—who understands the clinical architecture—would be a move to satisfy due diligence requirements. 3. The Takeover Protection & Valuation Angle As of November 2025, Feedback PLC confirmed it is subject to the UK Takeover Code. When a company is "in play" or expecting an approach: * They often tidy up their corporate structure. * Moving key assets (like the Bleepa trademark and operations) into a dedicated subsidiary like Bleepa Ltd makes the company easier to value for a potential suitor. * Shaw’s appointment could be as a "Safe Pair of Hands" to oversee this transition, allowing CEO Tom Oakley to focus on the high-level PLC management and investor relations during a sale process. Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is n

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hospital Trusts across the Northwest region will soon be able to share patients' radiology images through a new, next generation cloud portal. The Greater Manchester Diagnostics Network has appointed UK-based cloud consultancy “Shaping Cloud” to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal. The PACS portal allows access for clinicians to view images that are stored digitally at Greater Manchester trusts. Users accessing the new PACS portal will use the Greater Manchester Identity (GMID) platform, which was built in collaboration between Shaping Cloud and Greater Manchester Combined Authority. “ It’s interesting to note that Tom mentioned that FDBK were working with AWS in uk, who were interested in uk opportunities . Shaping Cloud whom have been brought in to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal in Manchester region is a AWS cloud consultancy company. If you read what Shaping Cloud aim to achieve , it exactly mirrors what we know Bleepa can do, and we are reliably informed Bleepa is apparently the only viable solution . First rollout in northwest region in early 2026….hopefully news in next few weeks in 26. data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/
data.thread_title: 2026 predictions: Health tech suppliers have their say..

data.author: Vascular
data.content: More accurately , it seems both EMIS ( Optum) and TPP cover most GP practices in UK. Key Provider Software EMIS Web (Optum): Used by around 58% of GP practices in England. It is a robust clinical record system integrated with the GP Connect APIs. TPP SystmOne: Used by most of the remaining practices, it has a single central record store across all GPs using the system. TPP was the first supplier to achieve a full national rollout for some GP Connect capabilities. Medicus Health: A smaller, newer provider that has also achieved full rollout approval for several GP Connect services. If in the future FDBK do win to supply nationally, then any early work , trials with Optum would mean thatFDBK would also need to be included in the other providers such as TPP, I guess.

As posted before the other three are TPP, FoT  and  Medicus , as far as i can see. We know FDBK are working with Optum and if this deal does go through , and Optum is sold to TPG -  this could open up doors in USA one day. data.content: Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" ​The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is not a coincidence. It marks the start of a "New Era" for the company. ​Summary of the likely "Something Occurring": ​Bleepa Ltd: Likely becoming the primary operational vehicle for the Bleepa platform, possibly to prepare for a sale or separate funding round. ​Brickshield Ltd: Likely being repurposed to hold "Shield" or security-related IP, or perhaps a specific NHS contract that requires a clean corporate vehicle. ​Dr. Rory Shaw: His return is a signal of Clinical Governance. It tells the market (and potential buyers) that the medical integrity of the platform is being overseen by someone who helped build the company's foundation. ​Conclusion: You are likely correct that "something is occurring." The activation of dormant subsidiaries following a period of poor share price performance and a CFO change is a classic precursor to a structural reorganization or a formal sale process. Take from the above what you will but changes seem to be round the corner. Gla and well done/thank you Vas for your research

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: So I cut and paste your post into Gemini AI: This is a sophisticated observation of corporate maneuvering, and the timing of these appointments—specifically November 10, 2025—is highly suggestive of a strategic shift at Feedback PLC (FDBK). When a dormant or "sleeping" subsidiary suddenly has a seasoned former director appointed alongside the current CEO, it typically points to one of three corporate actions: a divestment/spin-off, a joint venture, or a ring-fencing of specific intellectual property (IP). Here is an analysis of why Dr. Rory Shaw’s return to these specific entities is significant: 1. The "Clean Break" or Spin-Off Theory Dr. Rory Shaw was the Medical Director of Feedback PLC during its earlier growth phase (resigning in 2018). His reappointment to Bleepa Ltd and Brickshield Ltd on the same day that the group's CFO (Anesh Patel) officially stepped down (Nov 10, 2025) suggests a coordinated reshuffle. * Why Rory Shaw? He has "legacy" credibility. If Feedback is looking to sell off or spin out the Bleepa platform as a standalone entity to a private equity firm or a larger health-tech player, having a veteran clinical leader like Shaw on the subsidiary board provides stability and continuity that a "new" hire wouldn't offer. * The "Brickshield" Mystery: Brickshield has historically been a dormant vehicle. Its reactivation suggests it may be used to house a specific piece of IP or a new contract that the parent company wants to keep legally separate from the main PLC balance sheet—potentially to make it "deal-ready." 2. Strategic "Ring-Fencing" for Funding Feedback's recent 2025 presentations emphasized a "digital-first" NHS and the expansion of Community Diagnostic Centres (CDCs). * By activating Bleepa Ltd (the namesake of their flagship product) as a functional subsidiary rather than just a brand name within "Feedback Medical Ltd," they may be preparing to take on project-specific investment. * If a partner (like a Tier 1 medical imaging company) wanted to invest specifically in the Bleepa technology without buying into the entire PLC, appointing Shaw—who understands the clinical architecture—would be a move to satisfy due diligence requirements. 3. The Takeover Protection & Valuation Angle As of November 2025, Feedback PLC confirmed it is subject to the UK Takeover Code. When a company is "in play" or expecting an approach: * They often tidy up their corporate structure. * Moving key assets (like the Bleepa trademark and operations) into a dedicated subsidiary like Bleepa Ltd makes the company easier to value for a potential suitor. * Shaw’s appointment could be as a "Safe Pair of Hands" to oversee this transition, allowing CEO Tom Oakley to focus on the high-level PLC management and investor relations during a sale process. Why the 10th of November is the "Smoking Gun" The fact that these appointments happened on the exact day the new CFO (Emma Oswick) took over and the old CFO departed is n

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hospital Trusts across the Northwest region will soon be able to share patients' radiology images through a new, next generation cloud portal. The Greater Manchester Diagnostics Network has appointed UK-based cloud consultancy “Shaping Cloud” to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal. The PACS portal allows access for clinicians to view images that are stored digitally at Greater Manchester trusts. Users accessing the new PACS portal will use the Greater Manchester Identity (GMID) platform, which was built in collaboration between Shaping Cloud and Greater Manchester Combined Authority. “ It’s interesting to note that Tom mentioned that FDBK were working with AWS in uk, who were interested in uk opportunities . Shaping Cloud whom have been brought in to support the modernisation of its regional Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) portal in Manchester region is a AWS cloud consultancy company. If you read what Shaping Cloud aim to achieve , it exactly mirrors what we know Bleepa can do, and we are reliably informed Bleepa is apparently the only viable solution . First rollout in northwest region in early 2026….hopefully news in next few weeks in 26. G L vas https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation https://www.shapingcloud.com/news-insights/northwest-regional-imaging-portal-modernisation Greater Manchester upgrades PACS cloud portal for image sharing https://www.digitalhealth.net/2025/12/northwest-hospital-trusts-use-cloud-portal-to-share-radiology-images/

And the new CFO has dipped in too.  Yes not huge amounts granted but well, make of it what you will!

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Details of the NHS frontline digital productivity programme leaked online! The Frontline Productivity (FP) programme, which is expected to launch in April, will succeed the Frontline Digitisation programme, which aimed to support NHS trusts to reach a core level of digitisation, when it ends in March. If you click on the blue highlighted word “ Slides” you get the leaked slides.   Looking good.  cheers Vas https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/details-of-nhs-digital-productivity-programme-leaked-online/

data.author: Vascular
data.content: I may have misunderstood the following info but  FDBK have recently stated in September presentation something about having to wait for funding decision, could be anytime up until March  26 etc..something about “Spending review funding  for  NHS frontline for 2026-2027….” This was published in Nov 25.  its a scrutiny document / process relating to new  funding named as “Frontline Digitisation Programme “ and leads to a good conclusion ,  in confirming it will lead to value for money with this stated” I am clear that the ‘preferred option’ that is set out is proper, regular, feasible and offers good value for money. This summary sets out the key points which informed my approval decision.” And “ The programme has been subject to ongoing IPA assurance. A final IPA Gate 5 Review is planned for February 2026. The reviews to date have recognised the progress to mobilise the programme across NHS trusts and the well-developed organisation, governance arrangements and proportionate assurance framework.” https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/department-of-health-and-social-care-accounting-officer-assessments/frontline-digitisation-programme-accounting-officer-assessment#:~:text=Feasibility ,information%20sharing%20within%20the%20programme. So if this does pertain to the funding mentioned by FDBK then we are getting close.

data.content: Hi Vas, Many thanks for the earlier information. I hope the two are complementary rather than competitive as that would surely sideline Bleepa It appears to me that Miya is the connector or platform which will integrate Bleepa with other NHS apps. However, when you read a description of Bleepa it is also described as a communications platform! We shall see. Nice to see recent positive sp activity. Long may it last!

data.author: Vascular
data.content: I can’t find anywhere that stipulates that Alcidions products have medical device certification in UK.  Bleepa we understand does, and is either the only one available or one of a very few. On a AI search it states Software that performs a medical purpose, such as diagnosing, monitoring, or treating a medical condition, is classified as a medical device. Alcidion's solutions, such as Miya Results, Miya Observations, and Miya Precision, are software-based platforms used by clinicians for tasks like tracking test results, recording vital signs, and managing patient flow. “ To me Bleepa and Myra etc products are different, achieve different objectives and registered differently. iMO This modular system is a build it as you go , where Bleepa or other interoperable solutions can be added at any stage when required.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Hi Rebarm, This article may help. Cheers Vas https://www.alcidion.com/news/reimagining-eprs-for-2030/#:~:text=The%20cultural%20shift%20is%20from ,to%20platform%20as%20a%20partnership.&text=At%20Alcidion%2C%20our%20philosophy%20is,actionable%2C%20real%2Dtime%20insights.

data.author: rebarm
data.content: Thanks IB for the link and Vas for more detail. Keen to understand if this EPR solution is an integration API or a suite of applications. If the former then less likely to be an FDBK threat but then if the later could be. Checked out Alcidion's website and their solution is based on a platform, Mya Precision. Can't make out if it is the application glue for EPR or a suite of applications that might include a Bleepa challenge. Any idea?

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Thanks Bill Who know, could be important . The key phrase imo is… “ Hospitals across Sussex are preparing for a major digital upgrade designed to improve patient safety and provide more joined-up care. University Hospitals Sussex (UHSussex) has selected a supplier to deliver a new electronic patient record (EPR) system across all of its hospitals, marking a key milestone in the Trust’s long-term Excellent Care Everywhere strategy.” Note….“ to deliver a EPR system across All of its hospitals” As we know QVH  along with FDBK medical is continuing their work and extending the Bleepa reach and pathway's to community and other hospitals, possibly.  This was discussed at the Sept 25 Q&A…..It could be used as a  blueprint for  national rollout possibly,  but NHS wanted more connections and pathways . The seven NHS provider partners in the Sussex Health and Care system are: University Hospitals Sussex NHS Foundation Trust East Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust Queen Victoria Hospital NHS Foundation Trust Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust Sussex Community NHS Foundation Trust South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust Hard to imagine that FDBK not involved at some point. Providers can use more than one EPR as long as they are interoperable…FDBK will hopefully provide the glue to allow them to securely communicate with each other. https://www.sussex.ics.nhs.uk/about-sussex-health-and-care/who-we-are/ Alcidion is the EPR company that has been selected as preferred EPR supplier by University Hospitals Sussex https://hospitaltimes.co.uk/alcidion-selected-as-preferred-epr-supplier-by-university-hospitals-sussex/

data.author: Investor_Bill
data.content: Something & nothing maybe but we were quite heavily involved with Sussex: https://www.moreradio.online/news-post/sussex-hospitals-to-launch-major-digital-upgrade-with-new-electronic-patient-records

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Digital Health News asked health tech suppliers to share their takes on what they believe 2026 will bring. Read on for their predictions and expectations for the year ahead: “Shaun O’Hanlon, chief executive, Optum (UK) “Technology will be the engine driving delivery of the NHS 10 year health plan, enabling care to move beyond hospital walls through interoperability, care coordination, and data-driven patient pathways. “We’ll see a revolution in diagnostics and elective care, with intelligent, out-of-hospital pathways tackling waiting lists at their source in a more patient-centric and cost-conscious way. “Community pharmacies will increasingly function as local health hubs, integrated into care pathways and empowering independent prescriber pharmacists to help balance demand. “Underpinning all of this will be next-generation AI — safer, transparent, and supported by strong governance and human oversight — driving productivity and better patient outcomes. 2026 will see technology delivering measurable impact, reshaping care delivery at scale.” Also interesting comments from Sentra… “ Chris Scarisbrick, deputy UK managing director, Sectra “Imaging will be the pressure point in 2026. Pervasive workforce shortages and capacity challenges means it is an imperative to make imaging faster, more connected, and more intelligent. “AI will accelerate this transformation in part, but only if NHS systems and networks can confidently embrace fast-paced and at-scale deployment, learning from regions that have already excelled. “But real progress goes beyond sprinkling algorithms into radiologists’ workflows, especially at a time when diagnostic modernisation will be the make-or-break factor in NHS reform. “This demands a step change in diagnostic maturity, inter-disciplinary connectivity, and a willingness to modernise the underlying platforms that bind everything together. “The UK is already seeing impact where integrated diagnostics has been adopted in earnest: productivity jumps, clinical collaboration strengthens, and patient pathways speed up. In 2026, the organisations that break remaining silos will be the ones that move the needle.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2026/01/2026-predictions-health-tech-suppliers-have-their-say/
data.thread_title: 2026 predictions: Health tech suppliers have their say..

By leveraging Near Field Communication (NFC) technology, clinicians can securely transfer patient data between devices without an internet connection.” I recall Bleepa in India also had stated that Bleepa could “; “ An imaging pathway will ensure that x-rays can be transmitted even without networked connectivity, thanks to Bleepa’s cloud-hosted infrastructure.” https://www.digitalhealth.net/2021/12/feedback-expands-cloud-based-tb-programme-in-rual-india/ Avenue3 , as the consultants will need to pull together technology ( remit, is from SMEs) from different company’s so to achieve the tenders goals.  Let’s hope they choose Bleepa, as part of the solution.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Looks like some movement regarding the military Cortisone opportunity with a contract award yesterday via Project Mercury which is part of Operation Cortisone.  “Project Mercury application will enable military clinicians to view, record and share medical data on multiple devices whilst on global deployments, including in the most remote of locations where an internet connection isn’t possible. “ “News story £2.5 million contract to revolutionise deployed military healthcare Defence Medical Services awards £2.5 million contract to Avenue3 for Project Mercury, enabling secure military medical records access worldwide.” https://www.gov.uk/government/news/25-million-contract-to-revolutionise-deployed-military-healthcare The contract was awarded to Avenue3 “Why choose Avenue3? Avenue3 is the UK’s leading openEHR consultancy. We help healthcare organisations connect systems, take control of their data and deliver lasting results, improving care, reducing risk and future-proofing digital investments. “ A consultancy company that specialise in OpenEHR which is a standard FDBK  solutions utilise. https://avenue3.com/openehr

data.author: Vascular
data.content: More accurately , it seems both EMIS ( Optum) and TPP cover most GP practices in UK. Key Provider Software EMIS Web (Optum): Used by around 58% of GP practices in England. It is a robust clinical record system integrated with the GP Connect APIs. TPP SystmOne: Used by most of the remaining practices, it has a single central record store across all GPs using the system. TPP was the first supplier to achieve a full national rollout for some GP Connect capabilities. Medicus Health: A smaller, newer provider that has also achieved full rollout approval for several GP Connect services. If in the future FDBK do win to supply nationally, then any early work , trials with Optum would mean thatFDBK would also need to be included in the other providers such as TPP, I guess.

data.author: Vascular
data.content: Thanks for this Bill. This sector ( GP Connect) is heating up, and is a small, niche area, with limited competition imo.  the value in Optum is the recently ( 18 months ago)  bought company EMIS that is only one of only four company's in UK NHS  that  provides the software for , and link up GP Connect.   As posted before the other three are TPP, FoT  and  Medicus , as far as i can see. We know FDBK are working with Optum and if this deal does go through , and Optum is sold to TPG -  this could open up doors in USA one day. TPG could get access to both GP Connect and possibly neighbourhood Health services in UK. Things seem to be moving along faster these days.....
